column2: often simply Parma or PE for short
column3: is a journal of the Elvish Linguistic Fellowship dedicated to J.R.R. Tolkiens languages.

column2: as an irregular periodical published by the Linguistic Fellowship of the Mythopoeic Society. The first editor was Paula Marmor. It ran for five issues
column4: but resulted in the landmark book An Introduction to Elvish. Of that book Paula Marmor was co-author
column8: Lawrence J. Krieg and editor Jim Allan
column9: were regular contributors to Parma and parts of it had grown from their articles in the journal. The publication of The Silmarillion
column10: Unfinished Tales and The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien made most of the discussions outdated

column1: Another regular contributor was Robert Foster
column2: who had already published his Guide to Middle-earth
column3: which he revised and extended to The Complete Guide to Middle-earth after the publication of The Silmarillion.

column2: Chris Gilson revived Parma. He kept the original name
column3: despite the fact that the increase in Quenya material gave the correct translation as Parma Eldalambion. Gilson published Parma outside the Linguistic Fellowship
column7: p. 8 but after the Elvish Linguistic Fellowship was founded it became associated with that organisation.

column2: Christopher Tolkien approved of Parma publishing original text by Tolkien
column3: especially the long linguistic texts for which he could find no place in The History of Middle-earth.Christopher Gilson

column2: Vinyar Tengwar also started publishing Tolkiens original texts. Now
column3: they are both edited by more or less the same team
column4: and Parma specializes in the longer wordlists
column5: while Vinyar Tengwar publishes Tolkiens essays.David Bratman
column7: in: J.R.R. Tolkien Encyclopedia (edited by Michael D.C. Drout)

* 2001: Parma Eldalamberon 13: The Alphabet of Rúmil & Early Noldorin Fragments by J.R.R. Tolkien
* 2003: Parma Eldalamberon 14: Early Qenya and The Valmaric Script by J.R.R. Tolkien
* 2004: Parma Eldalamberon 15: Sí Qente Feanor and Other Elvish Writings by J.R.R. Tolkien
* 2006: Parma Eldalamberon 16: Early Elvish Poetry and Pre-Fëanorian Alphabets by J.R.R. Tolkien

column2: Phrases and Passages in The Lord of the Rings by J.R.R. Tolkien
